channel.title: Chloe Nguyen Portfolio
channel.description: Recent content on Chloe Nguyen Portfolio

item.title: R + Python = Friends <3 :)
item.description: You’ve probably seen those YouTube comments that say something like, “Take a shot every time someone says [insert word/phrase that has been repeated numerous times in video].” (Disclaimer: I am not advocating for anyone to actually do this challenge; you would probably get alcohol poisoning and die.) But did you know you could use R and Python together to count the number of times the word has been said?

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: class_diag<-function(probs,truth){ tab<-table(factor(probs>.5,levels=c("FALSE","TRUE")),truth) acc=sum(diag(tab))/sum(tab) sens=tab[2,2]/colSums(tab)[2] spec=tab[1,1]/colSums(tab)[1] ppv=tab[2,2]/rowSums(tab)[2] if(is.numeric(truth)==FALSE & is.logical(truth)==FALSE) truth<-as.numeric(truth)-1 #CALCULATE EXACT AUC ord<-order(probs, decreasing=TRUE) probs <- probs[ord]; truth <- truth[ord] TPR=cumsum(truth)/max(1,sum(truth)) FPR=cumsum(!truth)/max(1,sum(!truth)) dup<-c(probs[-1]>=probs[-length(probs)], FALSE) TPR<-c(0,TPR[!dup],1); FPR<-c(0,FPR[!dup],1) n <- length(TPR) auc<- sum( ((TPR[-1]+TPR[-n])/2) * (FPR[-1]-FPR[-n]) ) data.frame(acc,sens,spec,ppv,auc) } library(readxl) hcharperf <- read_excel("hcharperf.xlsx") perf<-hcharperf%>% select(host,condition,pupal.weight,sex,survival.larvae.pupae, survival.pupae.adult,time.larvae.adult) head(perf) ## # A tibble: 6 x 7 ## host condition pupal.weight sex survival.larvae.pupae survival.pupae.adult time.larvae.adult ## <chr> <chr> <dbl> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 P.

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: library(tidyverse) I chose a dataset on Coronavirus statistics with variables of date reported, country, new confirmed cases, new deaths, geographic ID, and European Union status. I also chose the 2019 World Happiness report dataset, which is based on a survey of global happiness by country and includes the variables for overall happiness rank among countries, happiness score from 1-10, and the following variables that indicate how much of each variable contributes to the overall happiness score: GDP per capita, social support, healthy life expectancy, freedom to make life choices, generosity, and perceptions of corruption.

item.title: Projects
item.description: Projects Here are some projects I have recently completed: Exploratory Data Analysis with Tidyverse Tools Modeling, Testing, and Classification
